item.title: Lethal Surprises Hidden in the Grass: Russia’s Trip Wires and Land Mines
item.description: As Moscow’s troops set booby traps in forests, houses and backyards, finding them has become a dangerous art for Ukrainian soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian de-mining team preparing to explode a hand grenade rigged to a trip wire, right, on the outskirts of Lyman, in eastern Ukraine, on April 3.

item.title: In China, Young People Ditch Prestige Jobs for Manual Labor
item.description: Some people who’ve walked away from China’s grueling corporate culture say it’s worth the financial sacrifice. “I was tired of living like that,” one said.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: China News Service, via Reuters
item.media:description: At a job fair in Wuhan, China, in February.

item.title: Saudi Arabia and Houthis Hold Peace Talks in Yemen: What to Know
item.description: The surprise rapprochement between Saudi Arabia and Iran, whose rivalry fueled the war, has raised a glimmer of hope for a breakthrough in resolving one of the world’s worst crises.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Shuaib Almosawa
item.media:credit: Yahya Arhab/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Houthi soldiers, top left, in the Yemeni capital looking down on a protest last month marking the eighth anniversary of the Saudi-led military campaign in Yemen.

item.title: Netanyahu Reverses Firing of Yoav Gallant, Israel’s Defense Minister
item.description: Yoav Gallant was dismissed last month after expressing concern about the pace of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s judicial overhaul plan.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Ohad Zwigenberg/Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, center, before his news conference in Tel Aviv on Monday.

item.title: Truffle Hunting in Syria, Once a Beloved Pastime, Is Now a Danger
item.description: A cherished spring tradition has become a perilous gamble to earn a bit of desperately needed income during an economic crisis after 12 years of war. Dozens of foragers have been killed already this year.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Louai Beshara/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A merchant sorting through desert truffles last month at a market in Hama, Syria.

item.title: China Brandishes Military Options in Exercises Around Taiwan
item.description: The People’s Liberation Army’s ships, planes and troops held three days of drills in a spectacle designed to warn Taiwan against challenging Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and Lam Yik Fei
item.media:description: A Chinese Navy ship near Dongju Island, Taiwan, on Monday.

item.title: Poland and Ukraine Reach Temporary Solution After Grain Supply Dispute
item.description: Poland, Romania and Hungary, all of which border Ukraine and are members of the European Union, have struggled with a glut of grain and other Ukrainian agricultural products since last year.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Marcin Bielecki/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Polish farmers protesting in the northwestern town of Szczecin last week.

item.title: Mexico Charges 4 Soldiers in Killings of 5 Civilians in Border City
item.description: The shooting deaths, in the cartel-dominated city of Nuevo Laredo, caused outrage because the people the soldiers fired on had apparently been unarmed.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Jasiel Rubio/Reuters
item.media:description: People argued with security personnel on Feb. 26 in Nuevo Laredo, Mexico, near the site where five people in a vehicle had been shot dead by soldiers earlier in the day.

item.title: China Sentences Leading Rights Activists to 14 and 12 Years in Prison
item.description: Xu Zhiyong and Ding Jiaxi were detained after organizing a small seaside gathering of activists to discuss human rights. Their lengthy sentences point to Beijing’s intolerance of dissent.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: An undated handout photo showing Xu Zhiyong, left, and Ding Jiaxi, together in Guangzhou, China. They were arrested after organizing a gathering of activists and lawyers in Xiamen in 2019.

item.title: Biden Must Tread Rocky Path in Northern Ireland Before Tending Roots
item.description: President Biden, who has ancestral ties to Ireland, will mark the 25th anniversary of the Good Friday Agreement in Northern Ireland before heading south.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Social Democratic and Labour Party (Northern Ireland)
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden with Leo Varadkar, the prime minister of Ireland, last month during a St. Patrick’s Day reception at the White House.

item.title: Italy’s Coast Guard Rescues Hundreds of Migrants in ‘Chaotic’ Few Days at Sea
item.description: About 2,000 people have been rescued since Friday, and ships were dispatched to help boats carrying 1,200 more on Monday as disquiet grows about the high numbers undertaking the risky crossing.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Giacomo Zorzi/Sea-Watch International, via Reuters
item.media:description: A boat in distress in the Mediterranean on Monday, in a photograph released by Sea-Watch International, a German organization.

item.title: Europe Has Pledged a Million Shells for Ukraine in a Year. Can It Deliver?
item.description: Probably not, experts say, given the shrunken state of its military industrial sector. A look at a major munitions maker helps explain why.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Andrea Gjestvang for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Arne Borresen, who oversees production of 155-millimeter shells, says Nammo is still working at peacetime rates, not wartime.

item.title: India’s Tigers Are Making a Comeback
item.description: A conservation effort has worked well enough that there is now talk of sending some tigers to Cambodia to help that nation revive its own wild population.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Satyajeet Singh Rathore/Associated Press
item.media:description: Tigers at the Ranthambore National Park in Sawai Madhopur, India, in 2015.

item.title: What Do Leaked U.S. Intelligence Reports Say? Here Is a Quick Guide.
item.description: Many questions remain about the classified documents that have been dribbling onto the web.
item.dc:creator: Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers near a frontline position in eastern Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: The Military’s Leaked Secrets
item.description: Officials are worried that leaked documents could damage U.S. operations around the world.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at a frontline position in southern Bakhmut last week.

item.title: How Ukraine Won the War to Keep the Lights On
item.description: Russia was determined to break Ukrainians’ will by plunging them into cold and darkness. Its failure, in the face of Ukrainian resilience, offers lessons as winter has released its icy grip.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: South Korea Downplays Leaked Pentagon Documents
item.description: The reaction to the leak in South Korea is perhaps the strongest so far as the Biden administration scrambles to contain the damage from apparent spying on allies.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Jeon Heon-Kyun
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III speaking with Defense Minister Lee Jong-sup of South Korea during a joint new conference after a January meeting in Seoul.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The investigation into leaked Ukraine war documents.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pentagon said little on Monday about the investigation into the leaked materials.

item.title: For Biden, an Era When Treaties Are More Likely to Be Broken Than Brokered
item.description: The president’s trip to Northern Ireland will mark the 25th anniversary of the Good Friday Agreement, which ended decades of violence. But such breakthroughs are harder to achieve in today’s fractious world.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden heads to Northern Ireland on Tuesday to commemorate the 25th anniversary of the Good Friday Agreement.

item.title: Clues Left Online Might Aid Leak Investigation, Officials Say
item.description: A large number of people potentially had access to the Pentagon intelligence documents posted on social media.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pentagon said little on Monday about the investigation into the leaked materials.

item.title: What Does ‘Wrongfully Detained’ Mean? What We Know About WSJ Reporter and Others
item.description: Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, is the latest American to bear the designation, which indicates that the U.S. government sees him as the equivalent of a political hostage.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Andrea Kannapell
item.media:credit: Evgenia Novozhenina/Reuters
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, leaving a court building in Moscow on March 30, a day after being detained on charges of espionage that the United States considers bogus.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: China’s Display of Force Around Taiwan
item.description: Also, President Biden prepares to visit Northern Ireland and Ireland.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Chinese Navy ship near Dongju Island, Taiwan, on Monday.

item.title: Dalai Lama Apologizes Over an Exchange With a Boy
item.description: In a video, the 87-year-old Tibetan spiritual leader sticks out his tongue and asks the child to “suck” it. His office said the actions had been lighthearted.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Ashwini Bhatia/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, in Dharamsala, India, in March.

item.title: Russia Adopts ‘Scorched Earth’ Tactics in Bakhmut, a Ukrainian Commander Says
item.description: Gen. Oleksandr Syrsky visited Bakhmut on Sunday and said the situation is difficult but under control.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier last week at a front line position in southern Bakhmut, in eastern Ukraine’s Donetsk region.

item.title: The Jailing of Evan Gershkovich
item.description: We tell you the story of the American reporter who has been imprisoned in Russia.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Claire Moses
item.media:credit: The Wall Street Journal, via Reuters
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich.

item.title: Northern Ireland 25 Years After the Good Friday Agreement, in Photos
item.description: As it commemorates a quarter-century since the Good Friday Agreement, the region is searching for its place and trying to move on from a legacy of bloody divisions.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Testa and Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: UK. Belfast. 28th March 2023 Children play next to a Peace Line that separates the Catholic and Protestant communities in West Belfast. These children are on the Catholic side of the wall. In 2013 Stormont’s Executive Office launched a plan to dismantle all Northern Ireland’s Peace Lines by 2023. Over the last ten years, 18 peace lines have been removed, but 60 remain standing, the vast majority of them in Belfast. The wall shown in the picture that runs between the Shankill and Falls Roads stands at 45 feet high.

item.title: Europe has pledged a million shells for Ukraine a year, but it probably can’t deliver.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Andrea Gjestvang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nammo, an international aerospace and defense company headquartered in the small Norwegian town of Raufoss, says it will turn out 200,000 artillery shells a year by 2028, a huge increase.

item.title: Diplomatic forums, the Security Council and India: What to watch for this week.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians taking a tram in Kyiv in February, after infrastructure attacks left it paused for two months.

item.title: Ukraine’s forces say they have so far thwarted Moscow’s efforts to sever supply lines around Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier atop an armored vehicle on a road near a frontline position in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A Ukraine war documents leak.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Every Day Is Scary’: Ukrainian Soldiers Learn to Cope With Trauma
item.description: A team of Ukrainian military psychologists is training soldiers to confront stress and trauma after a year of harsh fighting on the battlefield. But as Russia’s war grinds on, their work is getting harder.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak and Dmitriy Khavin
item.media:credit: Yousur Al-Hlou/The New York Times

item.title: Eight People Missing in Marseille After Building Collapses
item.description: The five-story building, near the French city’s old port, collapsed after an explosion whose cause was not immediately clear.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: Afp Contributor#Afp/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: How the Latest Leaked Documents Are Different From Past Breaches
item.description: The freshness of the documents — some appear to be barely 40 days old — and the hints they hold for operations to come make them particularly damaging, officials say.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leaked documents leave no doubt about how heavily the United States is involved in the war in Ukraine.

item.title: Leaked Documents Suggest Ukrainian Air Defense Is in Peril if Not Reinforced
item.description: A huge influx of munitions is needed to keep Russia’s air force from changing the course of the war, according to U.S. officials and newly leaked Pentagon documents.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Michael Schwirtz and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian police officers watching military aircraft fly over the Kremlin. Moscow could decide it is finally safe to unleash its prized fighter jets and bombers if Ukraine’s air defense systems are depleted.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Leaked U.S. Intelligence
item.description: Also, China conducts drills near Taiwan and the World Bank prepares for changes.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers around a front line position in southern Bakhmut, in Donetsk region, in Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: Canadian Police Technique Under Fire for Breeding False Confessions
item.description: A con game that undercover police use to obtain confessions in Canada secures convictions, but opponents say it’s a breeding ground for false confessions.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ifrah Farah at the Ontario Superior Court of Justice, where her brother’s killer was convicted.

item.title: Russia Plans Bounties on New Western Tanks, Leaked Documents Say
item.description: Unconfirmed reports from leaked Pentagon documents show plans to shore up troops’ morale and sharpen their tactics as Ukraine takes delivery of more advanced weapons.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian tank on a street in Siversk, north of Bakhmut, last month. Both sides in the war have long relied on Soviet-era machines.

item.title: Fight for Roads Into Bakhmut Has Hit a Stalemate, Ukraine Says
item.description: Even as Russian forces made some gains in the battered eastern city last week, Ukraine’s forces say they have thwarted Moscow’s efforts to sever supply lines. For now.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier riding atop an armored vehicle on a road near a frontline position in the Donetsk region, in eastern Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Tipping Confusion
item.description: Tipping norms haven’t kept up with delivery apps and changes in how people buy food.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson
item.media:credit: Ariel Davis

item.title: El Salvador Decimated Its Ruthless Gangs. But at What Cost?
item.description: In the year since El Salvador declared a state of emergency, the government has delivered a stunning blow to the gangs that were once the ultimate authority in much of the country.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Daniele Volpe
item.media:description: Soldiers on patrol on one of the main roads in Soyapango, El Salvador.

item.title: The World Bank Is Getting a New Chief. Will He Pivot Toward Climate Action?
item.description: Under pressure from world leaders, development experts and shareholders, the bank opens its spring meeting on Monday, poised for big changes.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Tony Karumba/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Ireland Readies a Warm Welcome for Biden, ‘the Most Irish’ President Since J.F.K.
item.description: Ahead of President Biden’s trip to Ireland, the locals of two towns, including several of his relatives, are hoping he’ll return to celebrate their ancestral ties.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s great-great-grandfather Owen Finnegan lived in Carlingford, Ireland, before leaving for New York in 1849.

item.title: Leaked Documents Show Seoul Torn Between U.S. Demands and Its Own Policy
item.description: The documents showed the United States most likely spied on a key Asian ally as pressure built for South Korea to help Washington supply ammunition to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jun Michael Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: A K9 howitzer at a test site for Hanwha Aerospace, South Korea’s largest defense contractor. The country has become a major exporter of weapons.

item.title: U.S. Sends Attack Submarine to Middle East
item.description: Officials said the move was meant as a deterrent against Iran and to maintain the stability of one of the world’s busiest shipping lanes.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Ronen Bergman and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Elliot Schaudt/U.S. Navy Central Command, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photo released by the United States Navy shows the U.S.S. Florida submarine transiting the Suez Canal in Egypt on Friday.

item.title: Israel Denies Leaked Claim That Mossad Encouraged Protest
item.description: The unsourced accusations about the leadership of the Mossad, Israel’s foreign intelligence service, were contained in a leaked Pentagon report.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of protesters took to the streets of Israel in March to demonstrate a proposed overhaul of the judicial system.

item.title: Leaked Document Shows the Dire Nature of Battle for Bakhmut
item.description: An assessment that appears in a new batch of leaked classified documents appears to show that Ukraine was close to losing a key battle of the war in February.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian armored vehicle carried soldiers near the front line on Friday in Bakhmut, Ukraine. According to a leaked classified document, the city and the forces defending it were in immediate danger of being encircled in late February.

item.title: What Leaked Pentagon Documents Show About Wagner’s Influence
item.description: The Russian mercenary group has extended its network for acquiring weapons — a sign of its reach, but also a possible indication that sanctions are forcing it to branch out from its Russian backers.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Evgenia Novozhenina/Reuters
item.media:description: A recruitment ad for the Wagner mercenary group in Moscow last month. Very little was public about the group before the Russian invasion of Ukraine, but it has now emerged as a main force in the war.

item.title: Overlooked No More: Alice Ball, Chemist Who Created a Treatment for Leprosy
item.description: After she died — and just a year after her discovery — another scientist took credit for her work. It would be more than half a century until her story resurfaced.
item.dc:creator: Delthia Ricks

item.title: Rockets From Lebanon Point to Growing Hamas Cooperation With Hezbollah
item.description: Israel accused Hamas, a Palestinian militia, of firing rockets into Israel from Lebanon, underscoring its deepening ties with Hezbollah, the dominant Lebanese militia.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Jalaa Marey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A member of the Israeli police bomb disposal unit walking past the remains of a shell fired from Lebanon on Thursday. It was intercepted by Israel in the northern town of Fassuta.

item.title: What Leaked Pentagon Documents Reveal About Russia’s Military Struggles
item.description: The information, exposed on social media sites, also shows that U.S. intelligence services are eavesdropping on important allies.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Michael Schwirtz and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new documents appear to show that America’s understanding of Russian planning remains extensive and that the United States is able to warn Ukraine’s military about Moscow’s future operations.

item.title: E.P.A. Is Said to Propose Rules Meant to Drive Up Electric Car Sales Tenfold
item.description: In what would be the nation’s most ambitious climate regulation, the proposal is designed to ensure that electric cars make up the majority of new U.S. auto sales by 2032.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden delivered a speech at a General Motors electric vehicle assembly plant in Detroit in 2021. The new rules would exceed his earlier goal that half the cars sold in the United States be all-electric by 2030.

item.title: Benjamin B. Ferencz, Last Surviving Nuremberg Prosecutor, Dies at 103
item.description: In addition to convicting prominent Nazi war criminals, he crusaded for an international criminal court and for laws to end wars of aggression.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Benjamin B. Ferencz, right, at the signing of an agreement between West Germany and Israel in Luxembourg in 1952. Mr. Ferencz helped Jewish groups negotiate a reparations settlement under which West Germany agreed to pay $822 million to Israel and to groups representing survivors of Nazi persecution.

item.title: French Visit Undercuts U.S. Efforts to Control China
item.description: Allies don’t always see things the same way, as Emmanuel Macron’s cozy visit to Xi Jinping made abundantly clear.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Thibault Camus
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, at a tea ceremony on Friday in Guangzhou, China.

item.title: China Rejects W.H.O. Accusations of Hiding Wuhan Covid Data
item.description: The rebukes came after overseas researchers discovered sequences that had not been previously shared.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.category: Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A hospital in Shanghai in December.

item.title: A Swedish Warship Sank in 1628. It’s Still Yielding Secrets.
item.description: Researchers are learning more about those who died after the Vasa sank, including a woman known as “G,” who was long believed by scientists to be a man.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:credit: Shutterstock

item.title: New Season, New Music
item.description: Looking for new music recommendations? Introducing an antidote to the algorithm.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Meet Jeremy Hansen, the First Canadian Headed to the Moon
item.description: Jeremy Hansen, 47, will be one of four astronauts on NASA’s Artemis II moon mission and the first from Canada to venture into deep space.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Go Nakamura/Reuters
item.media:description: Jeremy Hansen will become the first Canadian to fly to the moon.

item.title: Ukraine Says Russia Is Preparing to Evacuate Civilians From Occupied Areas of South
item.description: Ukraine is widely expected to launch a counteroffensive in the coming weeks to recapture territory from Russian forces. Some Ukrainian officials say it could focus on the south of the country.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Yurii Shyvala
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident outside her destroyed home near the front line in the Zaporizhzhia region of Ukraine in January.

item.title: The Russians Took Their Children. These Mothers Went and Got Them Back.
item.description: Making a nerve-wracking 3,000-mile journey from Ukraine, into Russia-occupied territory, and back again, a group of mothers managed to recover their children from the custody of the Russian authorities.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Daniel Berehulak
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times

item.title: In a Deadly Mountain Pass, a Tiny Hotel Is a Lifeline
item.description: Traversing the Sabzak Pass in Afghanistan is treacherous. But for travelers in distress, one innkeeper, who personifies Afghan generosity, is there to help — with a cup of tea, a meal or car repair.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Yaqoob Akbary and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times

item.title: Why Pope Francis Is the Star of AI-Generated Photos
item.description: Francis has become a recurring favorite to show in incongruous situations, such as riding a motorcycle and attending Burning Man, in A.I.-generated images.
item.dc:creator: Kalley Huang
item.media:description: A.I.-generated images of Pope Francis have earned more views, likes and comments than many other A.I. photos.
